Power to amend Schedule 2
	The Assembly may by order amend Schedule 2 by—
		adding a person;
		omitting a person;
		changing the description of a person.
	An order under subsection (1) may add a person to Schedule 2 only if—
		the person has functions dischargeable in relation to Wales,
		some or all of the person’s functions are in a field in which the Assemblyhas functions,
		the person is established by or under an enactment or by virtue of HerMajesty’s prerogative or in any other way by a Minister of the Crown, agovernment department, the Assembly or another person mentioned in Schedule 2,and
		at least half of the person’s expenditure on the discharge of its functionsin relation to Wales is met directly from payments made by the Assembly.
	But an order under subsection (1) may add a person to Schedule 2 even ifthe person does not satisfy the condition in subsection (2)(d), if theSecretary of State consents.
	An order under subsection (1) may not add to Schedule 2 a person whose soleor main activity is—
		the investigation of complaints by members of the public about the actionsof any person, or
		the supervision or review of, or of steps taken following, such aninvestigation.
	An order under subsection (1) must make provision about which of thefunctions of a person mentioned in Schedule 2 and specified in the order areto be relevant functions for the purposes of section 3.
	The provision that may be made by virtue of subsection (5) includesprovision amending section 3.
	But a function may be specified as a relevant function by virtue ofsubsection (5) only if it is in a field in which the Assembly has functions.

Power to amend Schedule 3
	The Assembly may by order amend Schedule 3 by—
		adding a person;
		omitting a person;
		changing the description of a person.
	An order under subsection (1) may add a person to Schedule 3 only if—
		the person provides a service in Wales,
		the service is in a field in which the Assembly has functions,
		the person is established by or under an enactment or by virtue of HerMajesty’s prerogative or in any other way by a Minister of the Crown, agovernment department, the Assembly or another person mentioned in Schedule 3,and
		at least half of the person’s expenditure on the discharge of its functionsin relation to Wales is met directly from payments made by the Assembly.
	But an order under subsection (1) may add a person to Schedule 3 even ifthe person does not satisfy the condition in subsection (2)(d), if theSecretary of State consents.
	An order under subsection (1) may not add to Schedule 3 a person whose soleor main activity is—
		the investigation of complaints by members of the public about the actionsof any person, or
		the supervision or review of, or of steps taken following, such aninvestigation.
	An order under subsection (1) must make provision about which of theservices provided by a person mentioned in Schedule 3 and specified in theorder are to be relevant services for the purposes of section 5.
	The provision that may be made by virtue of subsection (5) includesprovision amending section 6.
	But a service may be specified as a relevant service by virtue ofsubsection (5) only if—
		the person provides the service in Wales, and
		the service is in a field in which the Assembly has functions.

Assistance 
	Regulations may confer power on the Commissioner to give assistance to aperson who is or has been an older person in Wales—
		in making a complaint or representation to or in respect of the Assembly;
		in making a complaint or representation to or in respect of a personproviding regulated services in Wales, in respect of the provision of thoseservices;
		in making a complaint or representation to or in respect of a personmentioned in Schedule 3, in relation to anything done or omitted to be done bythat person the effect of which is subject to review under section 3;
		in making a complaint or representation to or in respect of a personproviding services on behalf of or under arrangements with a person mentionedin Schedule 3, in respect of the provision of a relevant service;
		in any procedure, proceedings or prospective proceedings of a prescribeddescription.
	The reference in subsection (1) to a person who has been an older person inWales includes a person who has ceased to be an older person in Wales beforethis section comes into force.
	A description of procedure or proceedings may be prescribed by virtue ofsubsection (1)(e) only if it relates to—
		anything the effect of which is subject to review under section 3,
		the provision of regulated services in Wales, or
		the provision of a relevant service on behalf of, or under arrangementswith, a person mentioned in Schedule 3.
	Assistance includes—
		financial assistance;
		arranging for a person to provide representation or give advice orassistance.
	The regulations may provide for assistance to be given on conditionsincluding (in the case of financial assistance) conditions requiring repaymentin prescribed circumstances.
	In subsections (1)(d) and (3)(c) “relevant service” means a service whichis a relevant service for the purposes of section 5 by virtue of section6(4)(f).

Examination of cases
	Regulations may make provision for the examination by the Commissioner ofthe cases of particular persons who are or have been older people in Wales, inconnection with the Commissioner’s functions under this Act.
	The reference in subsection (1) to the Commissioner’s functions under thisAct does not include his powers under sections 2(3) and 9, to the extent thatthey are exercised in relation to a field in which the Assembly does not havefunctions.
	The reference in subsection (1) to persons who have been older people inWales includes people who have ceased to be older people in Wales before thissection comes into force.
	The regulations may include provision about—
		the types of cases which may be examined;
		the circumstances in which an examination may be made;
		the procedure for conducting an examination, including provision about therepresentation of parties.
	The regulations may make provision—
		requiring persons to provide the Commissioner with information, or
		requiring persons who hold or are accountable for information to providethe Commissioner with explanations or other assistance,
			for either or both the purposes mentioned in subsection (6).
	The purposes are—
		the purposes of an examination;
		the purposes of determining whether a recommendation made in a reportfollowing an examination has been complied with.
	For the purposes mentioned in subsection (6), the Commissioner has the samepowers as the High Court in respect of—
		the attendance and examination of witnesses (including the administrationof oaths and affirmations and the examination of witnesses abroad), and
		the provision of information.
	No person is to be compelled for the purposes mentioned in subsection (6)to give any evidence or provide any information which he could not becompelled to give or provide in civil proceedings before the High Court.
	The regulations may make provision for the payment by the Commissioner ofsums in respect of expenses or allowances to persons who attend or provideinformation, explanations or other assistance for either of the purposesmentioned in subsection (6).

Obstruction and contempt
	If the Commissioner is satisfied that the condition in subsection (2) ismet in relation to a person, he may issue a certificate to that effect to theHigh Court.
	The condition is that the person—
		without lawful excuse, has obstructed the Commissioner or a member of hisstaff in the discharge of any of his functions under regulations made undersection 10,
		without lawful excuse, has failed to comply with a requirement to provideinformation which was imposed in the exercise of a power conferred byregulations made under section 6(5) or 10(5), or
		has done an act or made an omission in relation to an examination underregulations made under section 10 which, if the examination were proceedingsin the High Court, would constitute contempt of court.
	If the Commissioner issues a certificate under subsection (1)—
		the High Court may inquire into the matter, and
		if the High Court is satisfied that the condition in subsection (2) is metin relation to the person, it may deal with him in any manner in which itcould have dealt with him if he had committed contempt in relation to the HighCourt.

Guidance 
	The Commissioner may issue guidance on best practice in connection with anymatter relating to the interests of older people in Wales.
	Guidance under subsection (1) may be issued to—
		the Assembly;
		persons mentioned in Schedule 2;
		persons providing regulated services in Wales.
	Before issuing guidance under subsection (1) the Commissioner must consultsuch persons as he thinks appropriate.
	Where guidance issued under this section is applicable to a personmentioned in subsection (2), that person must have regard to the guidance indischarging his functions.
	In discharging his functions in respect of a person mentioned in subsection(2), the Commissioner may have regard to the extent to which the person hascomplied with any guidance issued under this section which is applicable tothat person.

Power of entry and of interviewing
	The Commissioner or a person authorised by him may, for the purposes of afunction of the Commissioner under section 3 or 5—
		enter any premises, other than a private dwelling, for the purpose ofinterviewing an older person accommodated or cared for there;
		interview the older person, if the older person consents.
	The interview must be conducted—
		if the older person requires another person to be present, in that otherperson’s presence; and
		otherwise in the presence of others only to the extent that the olderperson and the Commissioner have consented to their being present.
	The powers conferred by subsection (1) are exercisable at any reasonabletime.

Further supplementary functions
	Regulations may, for any purpose connected with the Commissioner’sfunctions, confer further functions on him.
	The reference in subsection (1) to the Commissioner’s functions does notinclude—
		his powers under sections 2(3) and 9, to the extent that they are exercisedin a field in which the Assembly does not have functions;
		his powers under section 13.
	Regulations under subsection (1) may, for the purposes of a functionconferred on the Commissioner by the regulations, confer power on theCommissioner or a person authorised by him—
		to enter any premises, other than a private dwelling, for the purpose ofinterviewing an older person accommodated or cared for there;
		to interview the older person, if the older person consents.
	Where regulations under subsection (1) confer power to interview an olderperson, the interview must be conducted—
		if the older person requires another person to be present, in that otherperson’s presence; and
		otherwise in the presence of others only to the extent that the olderperson and the Commissioner have consented to their being present.

Reports following discharge of particular functions
	Regulations may make provision about the making by the Commissioner ofreports following the discharge of any of his functions.
	The reference in subsection (1) to the Commissioner’s functions does notinclude his powers under sections 2(3) and 9, to the extent that they areexercised in a field in which the Assembly does not have functions.
	The regulations may in particular—
		specify the contents of a report and the persons to whom copies of a reportmust be sent;
		provide that the Commissioner may make a joint report with the Children’sCommissioner for Wales where they have discharged their respective functionsunder this Act and the Care Standards Act [2000 (c.14)](/id/ukpga/2000/14?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") in relation tothe same matters;
		make provision about the publication of a report;
		specify any further action which the Commissioner is required or permittedto take after making a report.
	Subject to subsection (5), a report made by the Commissioner under theregulations must not—
		mention the name of any person, or
		include any particulars which, in the opinion of the Commissioner, arelikely to identify any person and which, in his opinion, can be omittedwithout impairing the effectiveness of the report.
	Subsection (4) does not apply if, after taking account of the interests ofany persons he thinks appropriate, the Commissioner considers it to be in thepublic interest to include that information in the report.

Working with other ombudsmen
	Working jointly with the Public Services Ombudsman for Wales
		This section applies where it appears to the Commissioner that—
			he is entitled to examine a particular case under regulations made undersection 10; and
			the case is one which could also be the subject of an investigation by thePublic Services Ombudsman for Wales.
		Where the Commissioner considers it appropriate, he must—
			inform the Ombudsman about the case; and
			consult him in relation to it.
		Where the Commissioner consults the Ombudsman under this section he and theOmbudsman may—
			co-operate with each other in relation to the case;
			conduct a joint examination of the case;
			prepare and publish a joint report in relation to the examination.
		The Assembly may by order provide that this section is also to apply whereit appears to the Commissioner that a case could be the subject of aninvestigation by a person who is specified in the order as if references inthis section to the Public Services Ombudsman for Wales were references tothat person.
		Before making an order under subsection (4), the Assembly must consult theCommissioner and any other persons it thinks appropriate.
	Working collaboratively with other ombudsmen
		This section applies where it appears to the Commissioner that a case whichhe is—
			examining in accordance with regulations made under section 10, or
			considering whether to examine in accordance with such regulations,
				relates to or raises a matter which could be the subject of an investigationby another ombudsman (the “connected matter”).
		Where the Commissioner considers it appropriate, he must inform the otherombudsman about the connected matter.
		Where the Commissioner considers that the case also relates to or raises amatter which he is entitled to examine himself (the “older people matter”), hemust also if he considers it appropriate—
			inform the other ombudsman about the Commissioner’s proposals for theinvestigation of the case; and
			consult the other ombudsman about those proposals.
		Where the Commissioner and the other ombudsman consider that they areentitled to investigate, respectively, the older people matter and theconnected matter they may—
			co-operate with each other in the separate investigation of each of thosematters;
			act together in the investigation of those matters; and
			prepare and publish a joint report containing their respective conclusionsin relation to the matters they have each investigated.
		Where the Commissioner considers—
			that the case is not one which relates to or raises a matter that he isentitled to examine himself, and
			that it is appropriate to do so,
			he must inform the person whose case it is, or another person interested in itthat he thinks fit, about how to secure the referral of the connected matterto the other ombudsman.
		In this section “other ombudsman” means—
			the Public Services Ombudsman for Wales;
			the Children’s Commissioner for Wales.
		In this section “investigation” includes examination and inquiry, andcognate expressions are to be construed accordingly.
		The Assembly may by order amend subsection (6) by—
			adding a person;
			omitting a person;
			changing the description of a person.
		Before making an order under subsection (8), the Assembly must consult theCommissioner and any other persons it thinks appropriate.

Complaints procedure
	Complaints procedure in respect of the Commissioner
		The Commissioner must establish a procedure for the investigation ofcomplaints made in respect of his actions or omissions relating to thedischarge of his functions.
		The procedure established under subsection (1) must include provisionabout—
			how a complaint may be made;
			the person to whom a complaint may be made;
			the period within which consideration of a complaint must begin and shouldbe concluded; and
			action that the Commissioner must consider taking in response to acomplaint.
		The Commissioner may amend the procedure established under subsection (1)from time to time.
		Before establishing or amending the procedure under subsection (1) theCommissioner must consult the Assembly and obtain its approval.
		After establishing or amending the procedure under subsection (1) theCommissioner must send a document setting out the procedure to the Assembly.
